pullrequest.title: Static camera when following a model

content.raw:
It would be nice to have a working example. I added `<track_visual>` tag to `random_velocity.world` for example, I think it would be ok to either add it to that world or create another similar world as an example.

~~~
    <gui>
      <camera name="user_camera">
        <track_visual>
          <name>box</name>
        </track_visual>
      </camera>
    </gui>
~~~

So just with this default value, the camera seems to be moving with the model, but it is not oriented towards it, even though the SDF documentation says that "In any case, the camera will always follow the model by changing its orientation."
content.html:
It would be nice to have a working example. I added <track_visual> tag to random_velocity.world for example, I think it would be ok to either add it to that world or create another similar world as an example.

    <gui>
      <camera name="user_camera">
        <track_visual>
          <name>box</name>
        </track_visual>
      </camera>
    </gui>

So just with this default value, the camera seems to be moving with the model, but it is not oriented towards it, even though the SDF documentation says that "In any case, the camera will always follow the model by changing its orientation."

content.raw:
I'm experiencing a crash:

1. Open an empty world and insert a box

1. Right-click and "Follow"

1. Orbit or zoom the user camera - crash. Backtrace:

~~~
gzclient: /usr/include/OGRE/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h:264: void Ogre::AxisAlignedBox::setExtents(Ogre::Real, Ogre::Real, Ogre::Real, Ogre::Real, Ogre::Real, Ogre::Real): Assertion `(mx <= Mx && my <= My && mz <= Mz) && "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"' failed.

pull_request.title: Static camera when following a model

update.description:
The default behaviour of the user camera in follow mode is not convenient with aircrafts. This pull request introduces a new `static` mode that intends to fix this issue.

A new `<follow_model>` section must be added to `<world><gui><camera>` in sdformat (see related pull request [#238](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/238/new-section/diff) in sdformat).

With default parameters, the camera will remain at a distance of 8 meters from the tracked model (current behaviour of gazebo):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>false</static>
              <distance>8</distance>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In this other example, the camera will remain at the same position from the model (3 meters behind and 1 meter above):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <xyz>-3 0 1</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

Finally, we introduce the `<relative>` element whose default value is `true`. When `<static>` is true, this element specifies whether the coordinates provided by `<xyz>` are relative to the model reference frame or the world reference frame. In this last example, the user camera will stay at 10 meters above the origin:

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <relative>false</relative>
              <xyz>0 0 10</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In either mode, the camera always tries to remain orientated towards the model being tracked. When the camera is static and its position is relative, it also remains in the horizontal plane of the model (pitch and roll are ignored). All three parameters are configurable at runtime in gzclient.
update.title: Static camera when following a model

content.raw: There are a lot of conflicts, probably because this branch had been merged into `visuals` and then removed, so the merge tool doesn't know if they should be removed or not. Manually merging from default should fix it.

pull_request.title: Static camera when following a model

update.description:
The default behaviour of the user camera in follow mode is not convenient with aircrafts. This pull request introduces a new `static` mode that intends to fix this issue.

A new `<follow_model>` section must be added to `<world><gui><camera>` in sdformat (see related pull request [#238](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/238/new-section/diff) in sdformat).

With default parameters, the camera will remain at a distance of 8 meters from the tracked model (current behaviour of gazebo):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>false</static>
              <distance>8</distance>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In this other example, the camera will remain at the same position from the model (3 meters behind and 1 meter above):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <xyz>-3 0 1</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

Finally, we introduce the `<relative>` element whose default value is `true`. When `<static>` is true, this element specifies whether the coordinates provided by `<xyz>` are relative to the model reference frame or the world reference frame. In this last example, the user camera will stay at 10 meters above the origin:

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <relative>false</relative>
              <xyz>0 0 10</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In either mode, the camera always tries to remain orientated towards the model being tracked. When the camera is static and its position is relative, it also remains in the horizontal plane of the model (pitch and roll are ignored). All three parameters are configurable at runtime in gzclient.

pull_request.title: Static camera when following a model

pullrequest.title: Static camera when following a model

content.raw: The problem is that the camera is configured to inherit the yaw rotation of the tracked visual, and with a rolling sphere, this means that it will alternate between 0 and PI, hence the jumps. I added an option to configure whether this behaviour should be activated or not. For aircrafts, it makes sense to enable it by default.
content.html: The problem is that the camera is configured to inherit the yaw rotation of the tracked visual, and with a rolling sphere, this means that it will alternate between 0 and PI, hence the jumps. I added an option to configure whether this behaviour should be activated or not. For aircrafts, it makes sense to enable it by default.

pullrequest.title: Static camera when following a model

content.raw:
Currently looking into a problem here. My test case is:

1. Insert a sphere
2. Follow the sphere using the right-mouse menu
3. Put the camera is static follow mode.
4. Apply a force to the sphere to make it move along the x-direction.

The camera will jump back and forth.
content.html:
Currently looking into a problem here. My test case is:

  1. Insert a sphere
  2. Follow the sphere using the right-mouse menu
  3. Put the camera is static follow mode.
  4. Apply a force to the sphere to make it move along the x-direction.

The camera will jump back and forth.

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>false</static>
              <distance>8</distance>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In this other example, the camera will remain at the same position from the model (3 meters behind and 1 meter above):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <xyz>-3 0 1</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

Finally, we introduce the `<relative>` element whose default value is `true`. When `<static>` is true, this element specifies whether the coordinates provided by `<xyz>` are relative to the model reference frame or the world reference frame. In this last example, the user camera will stay at 10 meters above the origin:

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <relative>false</relative>
              <xyz>0 0 10</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In either mode, the camera always tries to remain orientated towards the model being tracked. When the camera is static and its position is relative, it also remains in the horizontal plane of the model (pitch and roll are ignored). All three parameters are configurable at runtime in gzclient.
update.title: Static camera when following a model

pull_request.title: Static camera when following a model

update.description:
The default behaviour of the user camera in follow mode is not convenient with aircrafts. This pull request introduces a new `static` mode that intends to fix this issue.

A new `<follow_model>` section must be added to `<world><gui><camera>` in sdformat (see related pull request [#238](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/238/new-section/diff) in sdformat).

With default parameters, the camera will remain at a distance of 8 meters from the tracked model (current behaviour of gazebo):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>false</static>
              <distance>8</distance>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In this other example, the camera will remain at the same position from the model (3 meters behind and 1 meter above):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <xyz>-3 0 1</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

Finally, we introduce the `<relative>` element whose default value is `true`. When `<static>` is true, this element specifies whether the coordinates provided by `<xyz>` are relative to the model reference frame or the world reference frame. In this last example, the user camera will stay at 10 meters above the origin:

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <relative>false</relative>
              <xyz>0 0 10</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In either mode, the camera always tries to remain orientated towards the model being tracked. When the camera is static and its position is relative, it also remains in the horizontal plane of the model (pitch and roll are ignored). All three parameters are configurable at runtime in gzclient.
update.title: Static camera when following a model
